pullRequest.body:
Added `@[aesop safe apply]` to `isSymmetric_zero, isSymmetric_id, IsSymmetric.add`, as well as to the following newly added theorems:
`isSymmetric.sub`, `isSymmetric.smul`, `isSymmetric.mul_of_comm`, `isSymmetric.pow`.

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

For details on the "pull request lifecycle" in mathlib, please see:
https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> Mathlib.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/11145839108/job/30976362138)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/11145839108/job/30976361666)

LGTM. I want another maintainer to approve the `aesop` attributes.

maintainer merge

LGTM. I want another maintainer to approve the `aesop` attributes.

maintainer merge

The name change will require a deprecation for the old name, and it will like cause some fallout which will need fixing.
```suggestion
@[simp]
protected theorem IsSymmetric.zero : (0 : E →ₗ[𝕜] E).IsSymmetric := fun x y =>
```
The way you have written this suggests that I need to declare a deprecation for the old name. Do I need to do anything other than change the name (and simp attribute)?

Yes, you need to add
```
@[deprecated (since := "2024-09-30")] alias isSymmetric_zero := IsSymmetric.zero
```
And you missed the `protected` and also `IsSymmetric.zero` should be capitalized.

```suggestion
@[simp]
protected theorem IsSymmetric.id : (LinearMap.id : E →ₗ[𝕜] E).IsSymmetric := fun _ _ => rfl
```
same issues here.

Without this you don't have dot notation.
```suggestion
theorem IsSymmetric.sub {T S : E →ₗ[𝕜] E} (hT : T.IsSymmetric) (hS : S.IsSymmetric) :
```
WOW! I'm confused about why the others above shouldn't also be capitalized, then...

They should now with the new names, but in Lean 3 we didn't have anonymous dot notation, so we didn't put things like that in the namespace, especially since they would need to be `protected`. But now, with the names suggested above, we can write `.zero` when the expected type is `IsSymmetric (0 : E →ₗ[𝕜] E)`.
Very cool.

because of the order of appearance in the conclusion.
```suggestion
theorem IsSymmetric.smul {c : 𝕜} (hc : conj c = c) {T : E →ₗ[𝕜] E} (hT : T.IsSymmetric) :
```
Very cool! I do hope I remember this style point later...

Because of the order of `S * T` in the conclusion.
```suggestion
lemma IsSymmetric.mul_of_commute {S T : E →ₗ[𝕜] E} (hS : S.IsSymmetric) (hT : T.IsSymmetric)
```

```suggestion
lemma IsSymmetric.pow {T : E →ₗ[𝕜] E} (hT : T.IsSymmetric) (n : ℕ) : (T ^ n).IsSymmetric := by
```

```suggestion
theorem IsSymmetric.add {T S : E →ₗ[𝕜] E} (hT : T.IsSymmetric) (hS : S.IsSymmetric) :
```
I have kept `@[aesop safe apply]`

```suggestion
  refine Nat.le_induction (by simp [one_eq_id]) (fun k _ ih ↦ ?_) n n.zero_le
  rw [iterate_succ, ← mul_eq_comp]
  exact ih.mul_of_comm hT <| .pow_left rfl k
```
This is cool. You needed to tell simp to use `one_eq_id`...also the dot notation on `zero_le`

```suggestion
  fun _ _ ↦ by rw [mul_apply, hS, hT, hST, mul_apply]
```
AWESOME! I was trying to do something like this.

I certainly don't think this should be marked `safe`, if we should mark it `aesop` at all. The 30% is just a guess. I don't think we have solid guidelines yet for this kind of thing.
```suggestion
@[aesop 30% apply]
```

Is this because of the weirdness of trying to resolve the various coercions appearing? I don't really understand `safe` versus `unsafe` beyond that `safe` are tried first, and that `unsafe` have a success probability. (So is the change you are suggesting marking this unsafe, implicitly?)

No, it's because `safe` lemmas will never backtrack. `unsafe` lemmas can be backtracked, and the percentage (which *does* imply `unsafe` as you surmised) tells `aesop` "how likely" it is to apply. `aesop` has a priority queue of which lemmas will be applied and the percentage affects where it ends up there.

Think of it this way: if you are going to prove `IsSymmetric (S + T)` (that's not a typo, I do mean `+`), then, unless you're in some weird situation, you almost always want to prove this by showing `S` and `T` are individually symmetric. However, in contrast, if you want to show that `S * T` is symmetric, it's only sometimes the case that you want this to follow from the fact that they are symmetric and commute (and moreover, this generates a `Commute` side condition that has to be discharged as well, so it could be more expensive to try this).
Ah!

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat(Analysis.InnerProductSpace.Symmetric) : Added several `aesop` lemmas for operations preserving `IsSymmetric`
